Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: Novel Material Platforms with Reduced Dimensionality for Next Generation Ferroelectric Photonics
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Ferroelectric materials are found in countless, widespread applications, e.g.: as barcode readers in grocery checkouts and as the devices that make today's Internet possible. Many of these applications exploit the ability to reduce the size of the relevant device features to micron dimensions and to tailor properties of the material by properly arranging ferroelectric domains. However, existing devices are based on bulk crystals or wafers with thicknesses of 0.5 mm or more. This limits the ability to produce devices that are more compact in size or are easily tunable in their function. This work aims at developing the materials foundations for new platforms with reduced dimensionality to overcome these limitations. The PI of this Materials World Network grant collaborates with two groups in Germany (Prof. Karsten Buse, University of Bonn and Prof. Detlef Kip, Helmut Schmidt University Hamburg) which are supported by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG, German Research Foundation). Through this international program, undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral scholars acquire a unique perspective in interacting globally through travel exchanges and workshops involving all participating organizations. Undergraduate research and exchange is a strong element of this collaboration involving Lehigh's undergraduate students and targeting especially underrepresented students. The team also contributes to the Lehigh Science Outreach program by organizing annual outreach workshops for high school students

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The project focuses on the development of two novel material platforms: (1) The lithium-niobate-on-insulator platform (LNOI) utilizing 3 inch wafer-sized crystal slices and photonic wires with optical confinement below 1 micron. (2) Single domain nanocrystals in sizes between 10-100 nm. The multifaceted approach of the team spans from solving basic science questions about the changes in bulk properties due to the reduced dimensionality and the increased role of surfaces and interfaces, to the development of specially adapted methods for domain patterning and the alignment of ferroelectric nanoparticles, to the demonstration of devices such as a cw-THz source and other nonlinear frequency converters. The team exploits its expertise in the fabrication of wafer-scale lithium-niobate-on-silicon-oxide as well as in preparation of mono-disperse lithium niobate nanocrystals and will utilize surface sensitive characterization methods such as near-field UV-Raman spectroscopy, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy and low energy ion scattering. The possibility of manipulating the orientation of nanocrystals will be studied in a novel optical tweezers instrument, which allows 3D control of light polarization and in situ Raman characterization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

                  Ferroelectric materials play an important role in technology for example in optical switches that drive optical communication that underlies broadband internet, in laser scanners at the supermarket or as the critical element within the commonly used green laser pointers.  The central theme of this work was to expand the usefulness of the material system by making it more versatile and allowing it to be used in more compact devices. For this goal, the international team from Lehigh University and two groups in Germany, explored the possibility to have such ferroelectric materials as a material platform with reduced dimensions.  The group at University of Freiburg developed methods to produce nanometer-sized crystals of the ferroelectric material lithium niobate. The group at the Helmut Schmidt University in Hamburg developed and improved the technology to produce thin (500nm) slices of lithium niobate on an oxide layer. This material class is called lithium niobate on insulator (LNOI). The group at Lehigh University characterized both these new material systems and developed experimental methods that allowed for manipulation of nanocrystals using a laser as well as determining the crystal composition. Jointly, the team was able to demonstrate low-loss waveguides based on this technology as well as the possibility to achieve the optical gain that is required for compact optical amplifiers and lasers.

As part of this grant, the Lehigh group also clarified the role that defects play in the vicinity of the interface that is formed when regions of different ferroelectric orientations meet within a sample. For applications, in which the material is used for converting light from one wavelength to another, up and down orientations are specifically engineered.  The finding by the Lehigh group helped in the understanding of the limits on how close a periodic sequence of up-down-up-down can come together. The work of the US-PI was published in 6 peer reviewed journal articles and 5 conferences proceedings and extended abstracts

Broader Impact:

The education of undergraduate and graduate students was an integral part of this grant. In the US-PIs lab, one graduate student finished his PhD and is now working in a National Lab.  Several other PhD and master students worked on subprojects and profited from the interdisciplinary and international aspects of the program. During the summer periods in 2011 to 2015, the PI hosted a total of six undergraduate students that came from groups that are underrepresented in Physics. Among them were four females, four African-American and one Hispanic student. All these students learned state-of-the-art technologies in optical spectroscopy and microscopy and several had the opportunity to spend time abroad in labs of the German collaborators. On the technology front, the work contributed to the commercialization of lithium niobate based technologies such as a new tunable laser systems (Hübner GMBH) and wafer-scale lithium niobate on insulators substrates (NanoLN).
